options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to a daily virtual seminar, there were weekly tutorial sessions that provided one-on-one help.
na
One-on-one virtual tutorial sessions each week.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Given that it is a heritage class, there was a larger focus on reading and writing compared to pronunciation. It also teaches grammar and a lot of Chinese vocabulary.
My ability to read in Chinese and hold a conversation greatly improved.
I gained the ability to better and more precisely communicate my thoughts in Chinese. I also learned and applied common grammar constructions.
More conversational Chinese speaking.
I became a more proficient speaker in Chinese and learned more about grammar structure, as well as new Chinese characters. I also learned more about the Chinese culture from the weekly readings.
I gained a better understanding of the grammar structures, vocabulary, and spoken word ability of Chinese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professors and teaching fellows were great. They made the class engaging and explained the concepts really well. The class is very rewarding, as you slowly become more and more proficient.
I liked how my class was small so we all had the opportunity to participate every day.

Liu Laoshi was an amazing teacher who was so kind and made sure that we all improved our Chinese from our own individual starting points. I can't really think of any ways that this class could have been improved.
Small classes really makes it easy to discuss the content and much more practice during classes.
For a virtual format, I thought the Chinese course was very engaging and created a great learning environment.

Strengths: Teachers had great energy, makes you feel welcome and at home

Weaknesses: Level of engagement suffered because there were no daily quizzes to force you to really know the material and also no student-to-student activities where you were practicing grammar and speaking with other students.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As someone who took Chinese L1 and L2 before COVID-19, the transition online was pretty seamless.
Zoom can be awkward sometimes but I think as long as people make the effort to turn cameras on and engage with the class, then you still get a good education from it.
The small seminars were successful in keeping me engaged and the short homework assignments/quizzes definitely helped reinforce my learning.
The drills for grammar and vocabulary were very successful. I thought each Zoom meeting was very productive, but I especially liked the small-group practice sessions for the weekly reading lessons.
The online quizzes weren't really that helpful - these quizzes should be done in the beginning of class like 112 and 122.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If you want to improve your Chinese skills, take it. It may be a little challenging if you go straight to L3 without any reading or writing skills, but it is doable.
Yes I would if they were looking to become more proficient in Chinese.
Yes! Definitely take this class if you want to improve your Chinese skills. The workload is not too heavy at all and Liu Laoshi just wants to help you grow and learn.
Yes, I learned alot!

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The Chinese professors I worked with were funny, engaging, and intellectually challenged me throughout the semester. I learned so much about not only the Chinese language but the culture as well.
Yes because if you want to learn Chinese this is the only course for it, but I wish it was more engaging.
